Hi Alistair,

thanks for the information! I will use that. The inaccessibil=
ity of JUnit
4.8 and 4.8.1 in public Maven repo is not a problem of course =
- I will
upload it to my company's repo.
Thanks again and have a nice day!
=

Gabriel



On Fri, Feb 5, 2010 at 2:02 AM, Alistair Israel <aisrael@gmail.=
com> wrote:

>
>
> Hi Gabriel, David.
>
>
> On Thu, Feb 4, 2010 at 9:44 PM,=
 David Saff <david@...<david%40saff.net>>
> wrote:
>
> > The good news=
: as of 4.7, basic per-test functionality like setting up
> > mocks works g=
reat in a Rule, and you can combine any number of Rules
> > with a Runner l=
ike Parameters.
> >
> > I'd first contact the Mockito maintainers to see if=
 they've already
> > considered writing a rule.  If not, I'm happy to advis=
e on how such a
> > thing could be built.
>
> Using a Rule to initialize mo=
cks (specifically using Mockito) was one
> the first things I used rules fo=
r:
>
> http://code.google.com/p/dirty-mockito/wiki/MagicMocker
>
> Note, ho=
wever, that as of JUnit 4.7 any mocks (to be) initialized by
> Rules will b=
e unavailable in your @Before test methods. This is fixed
> in JUnit 4.8 (@=
Before is executed after @Rules), but since that's not
> in any Maven repo =
yet I haven't been able to released dirty-mockito
> with that specific depe=
ndency. Of course, nothing's preventing you
> from using dirty-mockito and =
JUnit 4.8 (thereby getting around that
> limitation) in a non-Maven project=
.
>
> - alistair
> --
> http://alistairisrael.wordpress.com
>  
>
